thread.title: Froese ready for prime time in Leafs, NHL debut
thread.title_full: Froese ready for prime time in Leafs, NHL debut | Toronto Star

author: Mark Zwolinski
title: Froese ready for prime time in Leafs, NHL debut
text:
MONTREAL - Byron Froese will make his NHL debut with the Leafs Saturday night when the team meets the NHL’s current top rated team in the Montreal Canadiens.
For a 24-year-old former fourth-round pick of the Chicago Blackhawks, the stage – a Saturday night tilt between the Leafs and Habs – couldn’t be any better.
“This is where I want to be, this is the stage I want,” an excited Froese said as the Leafs prepared for Montreal at the morning skate at the Bell Centre Saturday.
Froese said he dealt with the nervous part of his debut when he was called up from the Marlies earlier this week.
“Oh yeah, I was able to sleep fine, there were more nerves the first day in practice,” he said.
“I just have to keep playing the same game I always play, get to the net and stick to the systems.”
Froese said his parents, John and Lottie, as well as his wife and brothers, are flying in from his native Winkler, Man. for the occasion.
That picture completes a winding hockey journey for Froese that began in 2011 when he played for Rockford in the American Hockey League; he’s made ECHL stops in Toledo and Cincinnati, and other AHL stops in San Antonio and Toronto.
His 2014-15 season began in San Antonio, who lent him to Cincinnati three games into the season. Froese had been on a professional tryout contract, and earned his keep with a breakout performance first with Cincinnati, then the Marlies.
He was loaned for the second time last season to the Marlies, and went on to score 18 goals and 24 assists in 46 games.
That led to an AHL contract last January, then a two-year deal with Leafs this past summer.
“Oh yeah, there were times for sure when you’re sent down (that you think you’ll never make the NHL).” Froese said.
“But you try not to think that way … it’s been a rollercoaster ride, but I always try to not let people say no to me.”
Leafs coach Mike Babcock said he has noticed Froese consistently working himself into consideration for the NHL ever since training camp; he has Froese penciled onto a line with Michael Grabner and PA Parenteau for Saturday’s game with Montreal.
The remaining Leaf lines shape up as follows:
James van Riemsdyk-Nazem Kadri-Leo Komarov
Shawn Matthias-Mark Arcobello-Brad Boyes
Daniel Winnik-Nick Spaling-Joffrey Lupul
It appears Peter Holland will be a healthy scratch; Tyler Bozak and Jake Gardiner are out with undisclosed injuries. Komarov did not participate in the morning skate, but he is expected to play.
The defensive pairings will see Dion Phaneuf and Matt Hunwick as the top pair, followed by Morgan Rielly and Scott Harrington, then Martin Marincin and Roman Polak.
Jonathan Bernier gets the start in goal.
